name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 28 November 2019.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: A year ago, terror struck Strasbourg in the middle of the city, even as Parliament was meeting in plenary. It is with emotion that we remember the deaths of this Islamist terrorist attack: Antonio Megalizzi, an Italian journalist who was in Strasbourg to cover the european Parliament's news; Bartosz Piotr Orent-Niedzielski, Strasbourger of Polish descent; Kamal Naghchband, a Strasbourg garage owner of Afghan origin; Pascal Verdenne, retired; Anupong Suebsamarn, Thai tourist. Terrorism does not concern the nationality, social origin or confession of the victims, it affects our entire society. In the face of violence and horror, we must remain united in defenders of the freedoms, values and principles that make up the European Union. Our deep respect and solidarity also goes to all the other victims, their families and friends, the City of Strasbourg and the French people. I invite you to observe a minute's silence in their tribute. (The Assembly, standing, observes a minute's silence). ***

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us remember the victims of yesterday's tragic event in the Czech Republic before today's sitting. At the University Hospital Ostrava, six of my fellow citizens died at the hands of the shooter. Innocent people who will never return home to their families and loved ones. A tragedy that should never have happened. I share the grief of the bereaved and would like us to offer our condolences.

name: Elena LIZZI
text: Mr President, thank you for this time for commemorating the memory and work of my co-regional, an Italian, who was, however, the father of the Erasmus programme and is therefore also a brother of this House. Domenico Leonarduzzi passed away last week at the age of 86 and, as you can imagine, leaves an unbridgeable void in the family, because of course he was a strong man, full of initiative and goodwill, but he also leaves the European Community a great memory and a great testimony of what can be a real common project to share , even if at other times our political positions see us very far away.  I should like to ask the House, if possible, to commemorate your figure at another point in depth. We did so in the EMPL Committee and I know that other Members have joined in this moment of grief. I would like to express to the family, daughters and grandchildren our condolences and our participation in personal and human mourning, but above all I would like to share with you the person, figure and work of the Erasmus dad and remember him here.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The final draft agenda as set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 157 of the Rules of Procedure, was distributed at its meeting on Thursday 28 November 2019. The following amendments have been tabled: On Wednesday, the Group of the Greens/European Free European Free Party requested that the debate on the Commission statement on the European Green Deal be concluded with a resolution to be voted on at the January I part-session. Lamberts to make the request of the Group of the Greens/European Green Group.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, today we are living in an important moment: this is the first political act of the new European Commission and it is an act of great significance in terms of all the policies of the European Union. I am delighted that the Commission has chosen to present it and give it to the European Parliament - I think that is the way it should be in a democracy. I also think it would be healthy for this House to respond to a substantial text of the Commission with a substantial text as well, in other words by a resolution which gives the vision that the European Parliament has of the general proposals of the European Commission. Of course, we will have the opportunity to vote on each of the Commission's legislative initiatives, of course. But I think it's also important that we can give an overview of what is an overall project. I therefore propose that we have, in effect, this resolution for the January I session.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the European Green Deal (2019/2956(RSP)). I give the floor, thanking her for being here, to President von der Leyen for her introduction to the debate.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: présidente de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, il y a deux semaines que j’ai fait une promesse à ce Parlement: je vous ai promis que ma Commission ne perdra pas de temps. Et voilà, à peine deux semaines plus tard, nous sommes ici devant vous avec notre proposition pour un pacte vert pour l’Europe, the European Green Deal. Ce sont les peuples d’Europe qui nous ont appelés à une action décisive contre le changement climatique. Les Européens ont fait entendre leur voix dans les rues et dans les urnes. C’est pour eux que nous sommes ici aujourd’hui, c’est pour eux que nous présentons un pacte vert pour l’Europe aussi ambitieux. C’est aujourd’hui que nous leur disons: nous vous avons entendus, nous vous avons entendus clair et fort et voici la réponse. Chers parlementaires, en juillet, immédiatement après ma nomination, j’ai placé l’action climatique au cœur de mon programme politique. Par votre vote, vous avez approuvé ce programme et je vous ai promis que vous auriez une place centrale dans les prochaines étapes. Aujourd’hui, Frans et moi, ainsi que tout le collège, nous présentons, à vous et aux citoyens européens, nos idées pour le pacte vert de l’Europe. Nous sommes aussi ici parce que nous avons besoin de vous. Cette proposition n’est pas le point final d’un travail, c’est le début d’un chemin commun et nous ne progresserons qu’avec votre soutien. Honourable Members, this is not just our vision for a climate-neutral continent; it is a roadmap for action, with 50 practical steps on Europe’s path towards 2050. It will take more than a generation to reach that goal. We know that this roadmap will have to evolve and adapt through the years. It will be a very long and partly bumpy road, without any question, but it is up to us to set the pace. It is up to us to leave no one behind, and we know that it is doable. We are determined to succeed, for the sake of this planet and life on it. And so many European people, businesses and cities, are already showing us the way. Last Friday, 44 of Europe’s largest investors, representing EUR 6 trillion of assets, called on the European Union to adopt, as quickly as possible, a climate law for climate neutrality in 2050. They want that law. They say it will give them the confidence to make long-term decisions for modern investment. It is about accountability and reliability, and therefore a crucial building block of our European Green Deal will be, in 2020, the proposal of the very first European climate law. It will set clear rules so that investors and innovators can plan their long-term investment. It will make the transition towards climate neutrality accountable and reliable. Next summer we will present a plan to increase our ambition in cutting emissions. This decision on our 2030 target will not be left to chance. The plan will come with a thorough impact assessment to better understand where we can be bold, but also where we must be prudent. We want to be as ambitious as we can and we want to be as realistic as we can. All of this will be ready in time for next year’s COP26 in Glasgow. Europe will lead by example, but we also need more ambitious multilateral rules for the whole world. Of course, every continent has to find its own path, without any question, but the goal must be the same for everyone, and positive change must be rewarded and not hindered. We want to protect our planet. We welcome the change in production procedures. If companies invest in clean technologies, if they respect our environment, it can’t be that they face unfair competition from heavy polluters, and that’s when we will apply a carbon border adjustment mechanism with full compliance with WTO rules. (Applause) Honourable Members, the European Green deal is not only about emissions: it is about boosting innovation; it is about quality food; it is about modern mobility. It will create new businesses and markets all across Europe. The European Green Deal is our new growth strategy, and this time it’s a growth strategy that is not consuming, but it is a new growth strategy that is more giving back than it takes away. It’s a growth strategy that is more caring. Companies from all across our continent are already turning the green transition into green opportunities and business opportunities. Some are converting plastic waste in modern furniture, for example. Farmers are using data from our satellites to adapt to climate change. Made-in-Europe batteries for electric cars are finally becoming reality. We must invest in Europe’s potential for innovation. 70 years ago, Europeans invested in coal and steel, and it turned out to be a historic reconciliation and an economic miracle. Today we are investing in renewables and algorithms, and the European Green Deal is about reconciling our economy with our planet, reconciling the way we produce and the way we consume with our planet, and respecting the environment we live in. That is the core of the European Green Deal. Honourable Members, exactly one year ago, the city of Katowice hosted the Global Climate Conference of COP24. This city, that for over a century was a capital of coal, became the global capital of climate action. Delegations from the whole world saw former coal industries that now host congress centres, restaurants and concert halls. This transition did not happen overnight, and it was certainly not effortless. Likewise, the European Green Deal won’t happen overnight and it will be demanding, but it is the right thing to do. As in Katowice, the transition will bring better and healthier jobs. It will bring cleaner and less-polluted cities. It will bring a higher quality of life for Europeans. But this transition will also need time, support and solidarity. Therefore, immediately in the next year, we will propose the Just Transition Mechanism. It will combine public money and private money. The European Investment Bank will leverage it, with the ambition to reach EUR 100 billion in investment over the next seven years. It will be the springboard for those sectors and those regions that have to catch up. Everyone in Europe can be part of this change. The transition is not just about big industry and coal. It is an opportunity for our farmers, with our farm-to-fork strategy. From Lapland to southern Italy, a whole generation of young farmers are rediscovering traditional crops and bringing new life to our countryside. The European Green Deal will be on their side. The European Green Deal will take care of Europe’s incredible natural heritage. It will protect biodiversity and revive the blue economy. But we, as institutions that serve the Europeans, must also walk the talk, and this is what the European Commission will do. We also have to learn what this change means in our daily life – how to practice sustainability. What does it mean for our buildings, for our waste management, for our travels, for our paper use, you name it? Today in College, we set ourselves the target to be, as a Commission, climate neutral by 2030, and I invite Parliament and the Council to do the same. It’s a challenge, but let’s do that together. Let us support active citizenship and call on grass roots initiatives. Let us work with teachers and educators, because our children are not passive spectators. They are very active players in this endeavour. Our climate pact will be with them and for them and for all those who are ready to play a part in this endeavour. Honourable Members, a whole continent has to be mobilised, from mayors in small cities and in big cities to all institutions on the European level. Every member of my Commission will be involved, every Member State, every committee in this Parliament. In fact, none of this will be possible without your support. We will need ambitious legislation. We will need a seven-year budget that rises to the challenge. Today, we bring the European Green Deal here to the floor of Parliament. Tomorrow I will present it to our leaders in the Council, and later this week Mr Timmermans will present it to COP25 in Madrid. Let’s start this endeavour together. Honourable Members, some say the cost of this transformation is too high. Well, let us never forget what the cost of non-action would be. (Applause) It is rising by the year. River flooding costs our citizens over EUR 5 billion annually. Every year, our economy is losing almost EUR 10 billion due to droughts, and farmers pay the highest price. And this is only the beginning. But this is not a given. We can resist these developments. It is high time, but it is not too late. With this roadmap for action, we make the cost of the transition fully sustainable. Many Europeans are already taking action. Only one year ago, no one would have imagined that millions would take to the street for climate. Our cities are choosing clean energy. Our scientists are developing the technologies of the future. Our families are renouncing plastic and choosing local food. Our European Green Deal is for them. It is ambitious. It is designed to be just. It is made in Europe for Europe to lead the way to climate neutrality in 2050. Europe has always given its best when it has worked together as a Union. We give our best when we are bold and aim high, and with the European Green Deal we are aiming high. Europeans are calling on us to drive the change. Now it’s up to us to answer their call. (Applause)

name: Esther de LANGE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for presenting today the vision, the plans and the ideas of your European Commission when it comes to the Green Deal. And for the EPP, for us popular parties and Christian Democrats, our motivation is crystal clear: we believe that we don’t own this planet; we’re merely looking after it for the generations to come, and we therefore simply have a moral obligation to protect it. And for us, what we discussed today, therefore, is not just a deal; it’s a solemn promise that we make to our children and our grandchildren. The President of the European Commission earlier today talked about a ‘man-on-the-moon’ moment, and she is right, because aiming for something that is so hard to reach takes a lot of courage. But we simply need to act; we may be the last generation that can still act and have an impact and make a difference. We only simply have a couple of decades left. And at the same time, for the EPP it is also clear that you don’t put a man – or a woman, for that matter – on the moon by just banning things, by increasing taxes and by telling people what they must do or what they can no longer do. We do it by bringing the best and the brightest together – that first of all. We need ground-breaking research: the smartest solutions and the cleanest industry which will provide jobs for Europeans and opportunities. Let Europe be the continent that develops and produces alternative aircraft fuels while also improving the rail market for shorter distances. Let Europe be the continent where we produce CO2-low or even -free steel. We in the EPP might not be climate warriors, but we are – and we need to be – climate nerds. That is what Europe needs to get ahead. We do it, secondly, by leaving nobody behind, it has been said; by not putting the burden, for example, on those who can least afford it. And this is a real worry among Europeans. We do it by working with our farmers and foresters: farmland and forests take up more than three quarters of our surface in Europe, and some brand farmers and foresters as the villains, as the problem in this debate, whereas they’re part of the solution. And we should help them, starting by ensuring them a fair price for their products as well as an international level playing field. And thirdly, we do it by bringing by being coherent and consistent. For the EPP it is clear that an ambitious climate policy and a smart industrial policy need to go hand in hand. A Green Deal without a good deal for our industry will not deliver the change that we are looking for. We want and we need ambition with the business case. And finally, we need a global, level playing field, it has been said, ensuring that other parts of the world either play along or cannot have uncorrected access to the European market. Today is a day, I think, for firmly putting that dot on the horizon. We agree on the direction that we are heading in. We share an ambition. But the work on how we get there is only starting. Let’s not fool ourselves. It will be challenging, and what we need is a combination of real vision and practical strategy, and this is what the EPP can and will deliver.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President. Madam President, today we have the opportunity to us us with a new era. For Europe and for our planet. Just eleven days after the start of the mandate, the European Commission, thanks to the extraordinary work of Frans Timmermans, presents us with more than just a proposal. What is presented to us today is a new model of growth, which aims to transform the European Union into a fairer and more prosperous society capable of responding to the challenges of climate change. Last November this Parliament declared the climate emergency. For the Social Democrats, this is not an empty slogan. This is a warning that requires urgent and exceptional action. The Green Pact points to the path that Europe and the rest of the world need to take for their transformation. It represents a total paradigm shift to definitively bury fossil fuels and achieve a climate-neutral Europe by 2050. If we are to achieve these objectives through a fair transition, we must rely on three pillars. The first is a green pillar, implementing the United Nations 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals. In this regard, we welcome the fact that the proposal makes our old aspiration to incorporate the Sustainable Development Goals into the European Semester a reality. And I am also referring to this green pillar because it incorporates climate law with clear objectives and the ultimate commitment to achieving climate neutrality. The second pillar is the red pillar, the social dimension of the Green Pact. Within the Green Pact we need a real social dimension. We only do this with a strong social pillar that allows us to transform our economies and ensure that no one is left behind. Disadvantaged classes cannot be most affected by climate change. And the third pillar, the financial pillar. This pillar will determine the success of the Green Pact. According to the Commission, meeting its objectives will require an additional annual investment of EUR 260 billion. To do this, we need the multiannual financial framework with at least 1.3% of gross national income and we need to talk about fair taxation, aligned with carbon reduction targets. The European Union cannot fight climate change alone. Our trade policy is an excellent opportunity to promote our labour, social and environmental standards. Today we send a clear message to meet the expectations of the millions of people taking to the streets by vindicating the fight against climate change. Those millions of people are ready for change. We, the Social Democrats, are prepared for change. The question is this, are our leaders and other political forces ready for change? The answer is obligatory. We have to be. It's time to act.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. –  Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, Vice—President of the Commission, the Green Deal communication is the beginning of a process to put Europe on the right track to fight against climate change, but we will succeed only if we change this challenge into an opportunity for our citizens and for our economy. If we go this way, Renew Europe will be a trustworthy but also a demanding partner. We led the declaration of a climate emergency and demanded the Green Deal be placed at the top of the agenda. If we want the Green Deal to generate opportunities, we must avoid adding bureaucracy to bureaucracy. The Green Deal must not end up with new red tape but with a new societal dynamic. We need to go fast, but we also need to engage in a wide debate all across Europe and mobilise around this project. First, to trigger change, we need to set the level of ambition in our future climate law and to set impact assessment as the standard. Second, let’s face it, the transition toward a carbon—neutral economy is, and will be, a challenge for many of our economic sectors and workers. It will call for massive investment, creativity and solidarity with the people and the sectors confronted with the most challenging transformations. Third, a twofold approach to Green digitalisation and technology is fundamental for us. Digital technologies are uniquely positioned to provide effective tools for climate-change mitigation and adaptation. And fourth, we should not oppose traditional policies and new priorities but modernise our traditional tools. Both the cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy can deliver on our new political ambitions. The Green Deal ambition must be integrated with policy reforms that are already on the table. Dear colleagues, this ascent ahead of us is the challenge of a generation. But with determination and teamwork, our journey can be an opportunity for our renewal and reinvention. The most challenging work is not only to set ambitions but to find practical solutions to achieve them, and you can trust that Renew Europe is committed to being an  active team member.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are delighted that the new Commission has made the ecological issue one of the major projects of the legislature and that your first political act is the presentation of a European green pact. Two weeks after you take office, it is normal that this plan is, at this stage, schematic. The question now is whether and how this catalogue of commitment and good intentions will be translated into concrete action. For us four criteria will determine our commitment to the Green New Deal. Firstly, it will have to ensure that the European Union takes its full part in the fight to limit global warming to one and a half degrees. So far, not only are the Union's commitments insufficient, but they are not being kept. Fixing the situation requires that, in the next 100 days, we commit to reducing our emissions by 65% by 2030. And climate change is just one symptom of humanity's failure to respect the planet's biophysical limits. We must also act without delay on biodiversity, on the subject of resource depletion or on the pollution of nature, a nature on which we simply depend for our lives. Secondly, to succeed, the ecological transition must be in solidarity, it must go hand in hand with a drastic reduction in economic and social inequalities. It goes without saying that producing and consuming sustainably is more expensive financially. To place the bulk of the transition price on those who suffer poverty, precariousness and downgrading is simply intolerable. The yellow vests rightly reminded us of it. Similarly, if this transition is rich in jobs, it will also destroy jobs. Those who occupy them will have to benefit from the solidarity of all and it is to this, and exclusively to that, that the just transition fund must serve. There can be no question that it will be used to compensate shareholders who have decided to choose fossil fuels. In fact, this fund is only a small part of the answer to the just transition. What we need is a profound transformation of taxation, so that those who have made the profits from the fossil age are also those who pay the largest share of the transition price. Third, the Green Pact requires the coherence of all public policies. For example, what is the point of devoting a part of the European Union's budgets to the fight against climate change if the other part aggravates the problem? Similarly, the Green Pact requires a profound overhaul of a common agricultural policy that remains productive and oriented towards the satisfaction of world markets.  And what, then, of the Union's free-trade strategy? Increasing trade flows on the planet again and again is absolute nonsense. So, in terms of coherence, Madam President, your project raises the issue, identifies the contradictions, but keeps them a little too much, for my taste, to decide them clearly. Finally, fourth point: the Green Pact has no chance of success if we fail to put finance back at the service of society. Since the 2007-08 crisis, the predatory DNA of the financial sector, at the heart of the evils that the Green New Deal intends to combat, has remained largely unchanged. Worse, today, the general climate is more of a deregulation, which is totally irresponsible. Colleagues, it has been sixty years, sixty years since scientists first began to link human activities to climate change; half a century since the Club of Rome warned us of the deadly danger of unlimited economic growth; thirty years since the Rio summit, where Jacques Chirac told us: our house is burning and we are looking elsewhere; more than 20 years since the first UN climate conference, and our greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise as resources run out and biodiversity collapses. It is time to fight low because to generalise to the whole planet, Madam President, this famous European way of life that you want to promote would require four planets. We only have one, and we depend on it for our survival.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, apart from the fact that I am new here, I really never imagined that I would receive the documents once in the Chamber and then have to discuss them. I mean, I don't say much, but at least have them an hour earlier and be able to read two sheets, but I don't. Clearly, democracy in this House is like this, it is a little inconvenient to give the opposition the opportunity to read the documents under discussion. I've heard of "50 Steps through 2050," a dream book, cover ads. Environmental neutrality by 2050: but have you considered the social and economic impacts of this? I understand that the Commission needs to have a somewhat fashionable image, because it is not that you are really loved, but it does not seem to me that shooting slogans, or chasing the Greta of the moment, is the right way. He talked about promoting innovation and quality food. I wonder whether 'quality food' means what we have seen with nutriscore, or Tunisian oil, or African oranges. I say this because Europe and the countries of Europe are being asked for standards, and then we magically see that you also make trade agreements with countries that do not have these standards. The same applies to plastic: keep talking about plastic free and then make trade agreements with countries where pollution is the order of the day. I have heard of made in Europe batteries, but do you have in mind that today 70 % of all batteries in the world are made in China, Japan and Korea?  I then listened to the evolution that has taken place from coal to steel and now, in short, the ambition of electricity. I just asked myself: is it not the case that some countries want to convert the production system at the expense of all European citizens? Perhaps this is a doubt that has only come to us, but, in short, it seems quite obvious You have talked about a hundred billion investments over the next seven years and then you are the same ones looking at commas and demanding compliance with budgetary constraints on countries when they have to fix their hydrogeological failure. I say this, of course, because I come from Italy, but this must apply to all countries. Lastly, I have the impression that for the second time we have heard the Juncker plan, the one that told the multiplier effect, namely that we would put in a euro and gain 1 500 % more, but that was not the case. I hope that you will have the capacity to have a vision of the reality of things and to go beyond the slogans that you are filling your mouth with.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, three points. First, we meet here in exceptional circumstances. We are discussing the sweeping changes to our climate and energy goals brought forward by the European Commission no sooner than 10 days since taking up office and before our recent, existing climate agreements have been implemented. This is ambitious, but it is not prudent. Point number two. In the ECR we had hoped the new Commission would be more cautious than the last one – that it would work with the Member States and within the Treaties. If you read the Treaty’s Article 15, it stated very clearly: it is the European Council who define the political direction of EU policies. And the European Council meets tomorrow to discuss: guess what? The EU’s long-term climate policy. So I ask myself: why are we here today? Is the Commission trying to seize the initiative, to take away power from the Member States? When we look back, we can see that in 2014 the European Council unanimously agreed the 2030 targets delivered with compromise after painstaking negotiations. And today’s headline goal of achieving climate neutrality by 2050 should have followed the same path, and Member State governments should not be sidelined on something this fundamental. Point number three, Madam President. In recent months we have heard so much about the green wave sweeping Europe. But have you noticed that, when this wave reaches the Baltic and travels down the Danube, it is not even a ripple? Why? Because in Central and Eastern Europe we can see through it. We see a confused strategy that prompts more questions than it answers. Are the Commission’s new climate goals credible and achievable? And what will this do to our industries? You pictured some sort of a paradise – who wouldn’t like to live in a paradise? But will this convince millions of Europeans? How have the new Commission, in 10 days since taking office, been able to fully understand how dramatically our economies could change as a result of this Green Deal? Have you an idea of the social costs as well as personal tragedies it will generate? Point number four, which I wanted to omit, but I will just indicate it briefly. It’s about gas. We see a completely confused strategy here. Gas is going to be an essential part of decarbonising in the coming years, and new legislation agreed recently prohibits future investment in gas. This is certainly confusing. So to conclude, Madam President. How we move forward has to be credible and achievable, otherwise you can have all the talk and targets in the world, but they will count for nothing if you can’t actually meet them. And when you try to do it by force, the consequences might be disastrous.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Madam President, today's debate is not a debate like any other, we are talking about a fundamental issue that transcends partisan divides: the survival of human civilization as we know it. We welcome the European Commission's approach to presenting its action plan before us, but let us say it now, any climate initiative will be futile if it does not tackle the root of the problem: an economic system that leads to both the destruction of our ecosystem and the explosion of inequalities. So some of your proposals, such as reforestation, state aid or energy efficiency, are moving in the right direction, but your plan is limited to objectives that remain unclear, non-binding and unfunded. One sign is no mistake: in your plan, there are many action plans, strategies that are set out, but few real legislative changes, when we know very well that we will not save the planet with incantations. Your plan is also riddled with contradictions that are fundamental and render some of its objectives inoperative. On energy, how can we be credible without a precise timetable for the exit of coal and gas and by further expanding an inefficient carbon market? On trade, what are environmental clauses for, if we pursue climate free trade agreements? On agriculture, how can we increase the area dedicated to organic without re-opening the CAP negotiations? On transport, how can rail freight be developed by continuing the dismantling of state-owned enterprises? Finally, on financing, where are the concrete commitments for a kerosene tax, a carbon tax and a plastic tax? As it stands, this plan will not achieve your target of a 50% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, already below the efforts to comply with the Paris Agreement. Worse still, and most importantly for our group, this plan ignores the human and social dimension of the ecological transition, so even - and you yourself have acknowledged - that the most insecure are the first victims of the disaster and it is not the derisory just transition fund that will change the game. This is a major political fault: we will not solve the climate crisis against the peoples or by making them pay the highest price, as Emmanuel Macron tried to do in France. The ecological transition must be made by, for and with the peoples of Europe.  So, in the face of urgency, Europe needs a real green pact for Europe, social and ecological, on a scale not seen since the post-war period. This is the meaning of the counter-project of our group of the European Unitarian Left, which we are putting back to you today and which we are putting on the table: concrete proposals based on ten axes. Firstly, the Green Pact for Europe must set a binding priority target in a climate law: reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 70% by 2030, and must launch a major investment plan to plan the transition to 100% renewable energy by 2050 and impose binding energy-saving targets on businesses. It must also initiate a vast thermal and energy retrofit plan to lift the 125 million Europeans out of energy insecurity; it must revolutionize our agricultural policy by encouraging a peasant model; it must move away from the logic of free trade and dare to show solidarity protectionism; it must put the Central Bank at the service of the ecological transition; it must free up budgetary margins by freeing itself from the austere straitjacket and combating tax evasion. These are the outlines of the ecological and social plan that we are putting on the table today, this is what the peoples and the planet expect, finally a pact for happy days, a pact for the future. You have three months to go before the final publication of the European Union's strategy. The European Parliament must assume its role and ask the European Commission to review its copy and increase the level of ambition so that the system and not the planet can finally be changed.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President von der Leyen, the objective of climate neutrality by 2050 is a good thing, and the many measures proposed, including the circular economy, reforestation and air quality, are still well in doubt. First of all, where we find the financial resources for transformation and for the climate and ecological transition. Because the European Commission tells us that we will need EUR 260 billion a year between now and 2030, yet the Court of Auditors recently said that it takes about EUR 1 115 billion a year, between now and 2030, to do what we have to do. So I fear, Dear President, that we are a long way from a plan of this magnitude, we are facing an epochal challenge that you yourself compared to the first man on the Moon. But are we sure that this European Green Deal has the necessary resources?  You have shown little courage on own resources: the tax on waste from non-recycled plastic packaging and the ETS quotas will not be enough. Furthermore, can you assure us that we are not talking about supposed leverage effects, such as those promised in your predecessor Juncker's plan? What role does the European Central Bank play in meeting the climate challenge? Finally, and I will close, if we are serious about having green investments ed off the Stability and Growth Pact, it is an essential reform that can no longer be postponed.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I welcome the proposal for more ambitious climate targets. If the energy transition succeeds in a cost-effective manner, Europe will have a good chance of developing the global strength of industry. Firstly, it is important that the Commission now provides for impact assessments to increase the 40% CO2 reduction target. Secondly, the prerequisite for a transformation of the energy sector into renewables is the unrestricted acceptance of natural gas as a bridge technology. Not only do we need this as a base load, but we also need intact gas networks for the transformation of wind and solar energy into hydrogen-based solutions. Thirdly, we will have to have huge amounts of green import electricity. Negotiations with states predestined for the sun and wind must begin immediately. The European energy transition must become the most important part of Europe's neighbourhood and foreign policy.  Fourthly, the energy transition must be market-economy and technology-neutral. In terms of market economy, the proven ETS of industry should also be transferred to transport and buildings. Technology neutral means allowing innovation. Today, an efficient diesel car is more environmentally friendly than almost any electric car. That will be reversed tomorrow, but that is regulated by the market and not by the green climate ideology. In this sense, I look forward to an interesting debate.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, President von der Leyen, Vice-President Timmermans, the next years are the time window we have to plan out the new economic model that we want to adopt, and the European Green Deal can be the industrial revolution that puts at its core social rights, workers’ rights, sustainability and our industry’s competitiveness. Any plan that is serious about delivering real results needs to be backed up by binding targets and measures, not only at the EU level but at the Member State level too. Gone are the days when Member States want to postpone and defer taking action. To reach carbon neutrality by 2050 we need a 55% CO2 reduction target for 2030 and to seriously consider an interim target for 2040. It gives clarity to Member States and industries where we want to go and how we want to do it, and no industry should be allowed to hide behind international mechanisms simply to postpone action. All sectors need to contribute, and that includes shipping and aviation too. Fossil fuel subsidies should be phased out and stopped. We need policies that direct investments to cleaner technologies across the board and in all sectors. We require innovative ways to generate new money for these investments. We need to discuss how best to mobilise public and private money so the right products are rolled out, good-quality jobs are created, and our current and future workforce is prepared for this transition. We believe that the European Green deal has the potential to brand this European Commission, and we are ready to work with both of you to deliver socially, economically and environmentally.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: There are requests for blue—card questions, but I’m advised that we don’t have time; we’re already running over. So apologies that we cannot take those blue—card questions. I would ask colleagues to stick to their time.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, today I am proud to be European, and it is thanks to you because you have presented, in ten days, the largest ecological transition plan for an entire continent. And as the United States withdraws from the Paris agreement, we are accelerating, and the Renew Group will be at your side against all those who want nothing to change and those who want everything to change tomorrow morning, when we know that this is not possible. And we want to stay that way because it's the only way to take society, to take the industry, to take our territories to reach the goal we have set ourselves: carbon neutrality in 2050. I stress that we are particularly pleased to see a climate law in 2050, but also a numerical requirement for 2030, as has just been pointed out. We want to reduce our emissions legally binding by 2030 by at least 55%. The second element of satisfaction is that you are changing the rules of trade agreements. From now on, the European Union will no longer sign trade agreements without, as an essential clause, compliance with the Paris Agreement. It is a new way of looking at globalisation, another element of pride, and the Renew Group will be with you, Madam President, Mr Vice-President.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Madam President, Mrs van der Leyen, what you are proposing would have been great 25 years ago, but we are not 25 years ago. It's 2019, and we're up to the wall in the face of disaster. What we need is a green pact for Europe that aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 65% by 2030, not 50% as you propose. Respecting the Paris agreement is a minimum. What we need is a green pact for Europe that turns its back on fossil fuel companies, that goes out of carbon and that stops all funding, yes all funding, for those who destroy our planet. Half measures threaten our future. You are talking about investing, but it is not EUR 1 trillion over ten years that we need to make the transition, it is EUR 1 trillion a year. You do not go far enough, because you still imagine that growth is a solution. You do not go far enough, because you still think that we have to spare the multinationals, the banks and the system that brought us right into the wall. The Green Pact for Europe should not be a timid development, but a real paradigm shift. It must be understood that the economy is not above the laws of nature. A real green pact for Europe calls for adapting our economy and legal framework to the environmental emergency. Strong measures, binding measures and a real duty of vigilance are needed to ensure that states and businesses finally meet their climate obligations. We need a new social and environmental contract, and we have no right to fail.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what I would have liked to say to Mrs von der Leyen before she left the Chamber – I hope nothing personal – is that I, in part, shared a small, and I stress small, part of her presentation. However, as a forma mentis, I believe that to improve one's needs to focus on the critical issues. Firstly, I wonder where we will find the money to finance what in all respects seems to be a re-run of the Juncker plan, given the sanctity of budgetary constraints. Furthermore, I would like to try to act as spokesman not for large investors, those who are able to mobilise trillions, but to speak on behalf of citizens and businesses that are deeply concerned about what the New Green Deal will be. These are the fears of those who fear that measures such as these should be reasoned in the long term and with the necessary planning, thus preventing them from being reduced to very expensive spots to satisfy public opinion or, worse still, to result in burdens that European companies, unlike those of third countries, will have to bear. For example, I am referring to Chinese pressure in the steel market. I wonder whether the New Green Deal will take responsibility for sanctioning China's non-compliance, or will it choose to ignore the stifling of our industry, as has been the case up to now. This is as if competitiveness is not one of the problems facing European companies most when faced with the aggressiveness of international competition. If there is a lack of competitiveness, market shares and jobs are lost as a result, and then it happens that companies delocaliise and paradoxically go to pollute in other countries. Thus, such a budgetary approach risks taking money from the next multiannual budget from key sectors, such as agriculture or cohesion policy. I doubt that the missing beneficiaries could go and say that their companies will close but will be able to enjoy lower carbon dioxide emissions. In conclusion, Madam President, I hope that the lobbies linked perhaps... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I’m sorry, I’m not allowing you to conclude because you are over your time. And before I go any further, why is it me who has to always deliver the bad news on timing? Because there is bad news on timing: we have 20 requests for catch—the—eye, but at the rate we are now proceeding, it will be very difficult to give the floor to anyone who wants a catch—the—eye. Those who get the floor, would you please respect your time? I will give you a warning after five seconds and then I’ll be ruthless.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Madam President, I will start rhetorically: why is the Commission convening this Parliament for the programme and not publishing it at a press conference, as has always been the case? I'm sure it won't be because of the carbon footprint, because we've only deepened here for those two hours as we've flown in from all over Europe. It is – yes – because the program is radical, it is called "Destiny", but it is actually a green revolution. We are conservatives and we do not believe in revolutions. Yes, we want to behave responsibly towards the planet, we want to protect nature, we feel this is our duty, but the price must not be the rape of procedures where one will roll over others, but also the disproportionate costs that will only lead to another revolution coming, which will take away the most precious thing we have, the friendly cooperation of the Peoples of Europe and freedom. The Green Deal must not become the new communist manifesto, this time in green.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, conservative friends can be at peace, the motion is nowhere near a revolution, unfortunately. After all, the recipe for combating climate change is very simple, emissions must be brought down, carbon sinks must be brought up and the flow of money must support ecological reconstruction. And all this in a socially just way. This contains a lot of good elements, but is it enough? In order to achieve the 2050 carbon neutrality target, it is necessary to ensure that the 2030 target is achieved and ambitious enough.  We have just declared a climate emergency and you are presenting an emission reduction target for 2030 that is below scientific knowledge. It's incomprehensible! The emission reduction target should be at least 65% if we are to be on a safe path. And it is also inadequate because the programme does not contain sufficient means to strengthen carbon sinks. The criteria for both agriculture and forestry must change fundamentally in order to strengthen carbon sinks.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Madam President, I have to say there are positive arguments coming from the presentation, but I still have many doubts about the feasibility of your ambitious programmes. We need a huge budget to realise the goals described, and we know that not all Member States are in line with this. As you reported, we have to prevent the tremendous cost of non-actions. We know we don’t have any other options and we do need to invest now. We have dual ambitions: the safeguard of our planet and the safeguard of our labour market. To ensure this, we need to invest in research. We need to simplify the legislation to give access to funds; we need more transparent dialogue with our citizens; and we need to pay special attention to the poorest regions of our continent. During the last plenary we declared a climate and environment emergency. This was a desperate bid to raise awareness. We can’t stand more words. We need concrete actions and we need them now.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Madam President, it is very good that we have this proposal on the table now. I hope that, when you drafted it, you discussed it with all the DGs and that the proposal did not come only from you, so that it was based on feasible proposals. You have a programme of legislation; and that's a good thing. I would ask you to review it in the coming period and see if the proposals are coordinated between the different areas, so that we do not cause problems for another area when we legislate in a particular area. I hope that all these legislative proposals will be based on an impact study for both climate change and the effect on jobs and economic competitiveness. I hope that all these proposals will be based on intensive consultation with the industry and on the technologies that exist now and that can be put into practice. I hope that you will take action with regard to the use of Horizon Europe. If it is still a state of emergency, as some say, then let us use Horizon Europe 100 percent for innovation and not for fundamental research in this direction, and then we will probably be successful. And I'm also asking you to review the Global chapter. That's where we have to... (The President withdrew the speaker's word).

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: – Madam President, first of all let me express my gratitude to Vice—President Timmermans for all the efforts he has made in the last weeks. I would like to take the opportunity to urge all of us – and I emphasise all of us – to let’s make this European Green Deal a Green New Deal.  Let’s look back. In the 1930s, the New Deal in the US, and later other demand—side economic policies in Europe, created jobs, economic growth and unparalled social equality. This is what we need to repeat for the green industrial revolution. Our investment in new greener technologies, such as battery production and green hydrogen, needs to be more ambitious and we need massive investment in modern infrastructure for green energy and transport, be it in big cities or in small villages. This is the way we should go, all together. Thank you once again to Mr Timmermans.

name: Chris DAVIES
text: – Madam President and Commissioner Timmermans, I cannot emphasise enough how important it is that the Green Deal be tinged with blue. We have to safeguard our seas. We poison the Baltic. We over-fish the Mediterranean. We declare marine protected areas and then leave them, in practice, unprotected. In some fisheries the catch that is thrown overboard still exceeds the catch that is landed, because the laws we passed are not enforced. But failure can be replaced by success. We can end overfishing once and for all, building on the achievements already being made. We can restore the rich biodiversity beneath our waves and help rebuild the stocks that will give a secure future to our fishing industry. By putting sustainability first, we will be well placed to lead negotiations globally in promoting good governance of the world’s oceans. Vice-President, we face many environmental battles; this is one we can win. So please, seize the opportunity. You have the chance to transform the state of the seas and make a real difference for the better.

name: Ville NIINISTÖ
text: – Madam President, the climate emergency is here. The science is clear and the youth are on our streets demanding urgent action. This is the backdrop to today’s discussion. I applaud the Commission. I’ve seen, as a former MP and Minister of the Environment, a number of Commissions, and this is the first Commission that sees climate action as a broad challenge that all the Commissioners have to address. But however broad, it is still not yet decisive. It has to be decisive, and this is where the Green Deal still is a programme of promises but not on delivery. Is the Commission ready to increase the 2030 target to at least 55%, to be even close to the Paris targets, or even higher? Are you prepared to have a broad reform of the ETS? Are you prepared to increase the energy efficiency targets and renewables targets? Because energy is at the core of the transformation that we are doing. 75% of our emissions come from energy, so we need to hasten the energy transformation. So we are willing to work with you, from the Greens’ side, but we demand decisive action and we demand it now. Good luck.

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Green Deal entered the race with three promises: the first was the reduction of emissions, the second the creation of jobs and the third the improvement of the quality of life. Reducing emissions is a noble approach. But the EU alone will not stop climate change – just 10% of global emissions are actually made in the EU. The commissioning of 300 new coal-fired power plants in China alone will make all the EU's hard and expensive savings obsolete. Whether the measures of the Green Deal will ultimately benefit the global climate is in the stars. What is certain at the moment, however, is above all one thing, namely the further strain and gearing of our citizens for energy and for transport. The massive cuts in the German and European car industry are also certain, with Nine and a half thousand jobs to be lost at Audi in my home town, for example, by 2025. So the EU is already heading for recession. With your Green Deal, you, Madam President of the Commission, are throwing a stick between the legs of an already stumbling woman. We need a change of mentality, we need freedom instead of subsidies, we need a clear framework, we need predictability, predictability and legal certainty. This also means real compliance with the technology neutrality originally demanded and promised in the promotion of future means of transport. Let us finally renounce your control fantasies, Commission, and give our companies freedom to make decisions again!

name: Pietro FIOCCHI
text: – Madam President, and dear missing President of the Commission, Ms von der Leyen – I hope this is not a sign of the times to come: that she thinks she can avoid listening to a democratically—elected parliament – I want to state that I am 110% behind the new Green Deal, but I have two strong demands to the – missing – Commission President, Ms von der Leyen. Number one: force the US, India and China to follow our path, because otherwise our New Green Deal will be useless and counter—productive. Number two: when you devise the operative plan to reach the goal, put business and companies and jobs as the highest priority, because we do not want all industries to relocate to Africa, to Turkey or to the US.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Madam President, you are talking about ambition, but at the same time with this plan, I am sure you will disappoint Lisette. Lisette started working at 15 and now she has a pension of 570 euros a month. What do you propose on page 5? You are proposing to increase the European carbon tax. This is unacceptable. It is exactly against this carbon tax that the yellow vests have revolted in France, Belgium and elsewhere and this, frankly, we cannot accept it. Today, there are 125 million Europeans living in energy poverty, who cannot heat themselves in the winter, who cannot live with dignity by turning on the light. It is unacceptable to make the Europeans pay for this green pact for Europe, that is the first point. I come to my second point. Ik denk dat u ook Apolline gaat teleurstellen, een studente die iedere week, iedere maand de straat opgaat voor radical maatregelen en die ziet dat u spreekt over openbare investeringen, maar niet breekt met de besparingslogica. Die ziet dat u spreekt over schone energie, maar toch niet breekt puts het ETS-systeem, met de emissiehandel. Hoe legt u dat uit?

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, at a time of fierce competition between imperialist centres — such as the European Union, the USA, China, Russia — but also among energy giants, the Green Agreement is tangible proof that climate change is being used as a pretext to give plenty of money to large groups in the race with their competitors. The European Union rewards the great interests, which pollute the environment, with Green Funds and investments of EUR trillion by 2030, while punishing grassroots families with all the inspirational green taxation, cultivating the dangerous perception of individual responsibility. The real concerns of the peoples for the protection of the environment have nothing to do with the system of trade in pollutants, with the export of waste, with the logic of 'polluter pays' — with logics that only recycle problems. Capitalists and their associations commercialize and destroy the environment with the aim of maximum profit. That's why they're burdening the climate. Only a centrally designed economy, without exploitation, imperialist wars and monopolies, can meet modern social needs and ensure the life and health of the population, as well as the protection of the environment.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, if Europe leads the fight against climate change in the world today, it is thanks to the leadership of the European People's Party. With Juncker and Arias Cañete; achievements such as the Paris Agreement. But we don't settle. We must convince and demand all regions of the world to match our ambition. Let's export our knowledge and our good management to achieve a cleaner and healthier planet. We want Europe to teach the world to join the fight against climate change. And the best way to do this is with the leadership of Ursula von der Leyen and the Green Pact. But in this great global challenge that we all have, neither the denialism of the far right nor the hysteria of the far left can fit. This great challenge needs unity, rigor, responsibility and leaving no one behind. The fight against climate change must always go hand in hand with economic growth, more and better jobs, with all productive sectors and all citizens. They ⸻the workers, businesses, the self-employed, farmers, ranchers, fishermen, families⸻ are the main protagonists and affected of this transformation towards a circular, clean, responsible and competitive economy. Therefore, we must give them all the tools, all the economic, social, legal, training, and also impact resources, so as not to leave anyone behind. I don't want to end without giving a message to young people, because they are the future of the world. Your best ally is the European People's Party, a faithful ally who will take care of your opportunities, Europe and the planet like no one else. Because the European People's Party has always been the protagonist of the great transformations.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Vice-Chairman Timmermans, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his I have just returned from Madrid, where negotiations on our future are ongoing. I want europe and Europe to become the world's first climate-neutral continent. It requires courage, and it requires political leadership, not only locally and regionally, but also nationally in the Member States and here in the European Parliament. We Social Democrats take that leadership. Europe must change not only economically, ecologically and socially, but also fairly and equally.  In my country, Sweden, we have a government that has adopted a climate law. A very ambitious climate law has also been decided in Finland and most recently in Denmark. It is time for europe to do so too. We must invest in green innovation and jobs because it provides green growth. The Green Deal is here to stay. It meets the future of our children and grandchildren.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commission very much for its very promising communication. It looks as if, after so many previous generations have ignored calls for decisive action, we finally have a Commission that seems to care about our future. I can’t wait to see these ambitious plans in the form of real legislation, because we have a very long way to go to deliver the Green New Deal historic accomplishment. It won’t be easy. The Commission is ready; this Parliament is, for sure, ready; Renew Europe is ready. But I’m looking over to the Council. Are you ready as well? Because at the moment we still have three Member States blocking the EU’s climate neutrality target, including my own country, Hungary. We are still unsure if we will get an MFF that will cater for our ambitious goals, and this is very disappointing. I hope that we can ensure that real climate action does not fall hostage to power politics and backdoor compromises and that we can fulfil the promise of a safe and sustainable future for all.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work Today I really like to be a European here. This is a good day: in parallel with the climate conference in Madrid, an ambitious programme of measures by the European Commission. That is a good thing, and it is also right not to be chased into the fencing. Strong climate protection is a prerequisite for jobs, competitiveness and innovation, not the opposite. We must not allow ourselves to be held back by the eternally yesterdays.  I have more doubts as to whether this agenda is social enough. It is true that we need strong energy taxes, that we need to reform emissions trading. However, given the great inequalities in our societies, the revenue from these taxes must be repaid to the citizens per capita, otherwise we will not win the support of the people. And there is no such strong social dimension in your proposals.  Otherwise, we will support your proposals constructively. We want more ambitions in trade policy, in agricultural policy, in chemical policy. But we are on the right track together. Let us act now!

name: Herve JUVIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is an important moment, indeed. This is the first time that, in our Assembly, all our economic and political choices will have to be subordinated to the science of complex living systems that is ecology. This leads me to remind you that the issue of climate change is not the only, or even the most important. The poisoning of soils, waters and air, the race at least maintained by free trade treaties, are also major problems, but we would like to point out that the extinction of the diversity of human societies, our common treasure, is probably an ecological problem even more important than the extinction of the diversity of animal and plant species. This leads us to remind us that a state in full possession of its territory is the only one capable of dealing with ecological emergencies. This also leads us to remind us that a nation that guarantees its borders, the identity and the unity of its people is also the only one capable of dealing with the ecological emergency and that, on the other hand, the family, the place of transmission of the responsibility of a territory, which we strive to transmit more beautiful, richer and more alive to future generations, is the only one capable of helping us to respond to ecological emergencies. All this leads us in the future to pay attention to several points, and first of all, to the point that regulatory capture biases do not disadvantage these SMEs which are the origin of the majority of activity in our territories, to the benefit of multinationals or globalist actors. This also leads us to be careful that behind the Green Pact for Europe is not the trap of uniformity of modes of doing, practices and modes of production, which would destroy our customs, our traditions and the singularity of the mores of our territories, which make the diversity of our societies and which, somewhere, somewhere , are a response to energy challenges. Finally, as a Frenchman, I can only stress our attention to the treatment of nuclear power. Civil and military nuclear power are totally linked, for us it is an energy of the future, but it is also, for us, the condition of France's strategic independence and perhaps the pillar of a Europe of defence. Our debate to all of us, ladies and gentlemen, is to make desirable, what is desirable and what is vital. I hope that we will rise to that challenge.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, colleagues, further steps for a sustainable future are urgently needed, so much is now clear. But what we need today above all are concrete, workable and financeable solutions. They will have to come mainly from innovation. You are indeed proposing an integrated plan incorporating climate, economy, entrepreneurship and innovation, which is very positive. Your emphasis on circular economy is also very commendable. What is lacking, however, is a concrete, clear funding base that is right. By tackling it in this way, you run a double risk. On the one hand, you are not in danger of meeting your targets in the end. This certainly increases that risk. On the other hand, you also run the risk of losing the public's trust along the way. Finally, I would like to point out that only 10% of Europe's CO2 emissions come. That's often forgotten here. You want to be a geopolitical Commission. Please take that into that geopolitical mission.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, I’m glad to see that dealing with one of the greatest global challenges, climate change, has become a top priority for the new Commission. This is a historic step indeed, and I’m very glad to take part in this debate on a proposal for the Green Deal. There is no question that Europe, in this debate, must take the lead globally and set ambitious targets. But these targets must be realistic, they must be measurable, and they also must be feasible – and not by 2050, but much earlier; possibly by the end of the tenure of the Commission. So I would like to see some intermediate targets, whereby by this Commission becomes accountable for the targets that it is setting. Of course, we also must state that we have wasted over a decade, when there was abundant finance and abundant liquidity on the global markets, so we need to set those operative targets and those operative programmes on which we can invest and we can take the ... (The President cut-off the speaker)

name: Norbert LINS
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We can be proud: today we have an ambitious roadmap for climate-neutral Europe by 2050. However, despite all the ambition, we must not abruptly change any objectives that have already been agreed. Planning security is essential for the continued commitment of all sectors and technology leadership in the world. When it comes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, it is particularly important to me that not only reduction potentials but also storage potentials are made optimal use. I therefore very much welcome the fact that, in addition to a reforestation strategy, incentives for sustainable and active forest and land management should also be enshrined in the new European forestry strategy. Agriculture is less of a part of the problem than a significant part of the solution. The farm-to-fork strategy is also positively assessed. However, we need to establish a precise impact assessment so that, for example, we do not make the wrong decisions on the use of plant protection products.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Timmermans, with our colleagues in the Bureau of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, we are returning today from Madrid, where the international climate conference, COP25, is taking place. Can we say we have our eyes on us? That Europe has its eyes on it? They look to the Green New Deal not only the new generations, those who demonstrate in squares all over the world because they want a cleaner planet and more attention to our planet, but also the economic world looks to the Green New Deal as a lever for the competitiveness of our industrial system. That is why we must move on to action. We know vice president Timmermans' determination to work on the circular economy and the fight against plastic pollution, so we are very confident. To turn to the facts, I would like to make two points. One: resources. If we want industries that pollute less, cleaner means of transport in our cities, buildings with solar panels and recyclable, reusable and repairable products, we need a lot of investment. Without turning around, this means a multi-year financial plan that lives up to the challenge...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: – Madam President, this Green Deal can be the start for a whole new economy in Europe. Rightly handled, and if we are able to manage it working together, we can create new jobs, we will create new industry, new technology, it will create the start of a new era – the Green era, where we’re moving away from the fossil-based economy to the green economy. That is why I’m a bit concerned that still lacking in the documents I’ve seen so far is the whole part on the bioeconomy, which provides us with a huge opportunity to move away from chemicals and fossil-based materials towards the green-based materials. That is a huge opportunity, creating jobs all across the European Union. This might also help us to get a new boom in the European economy. Some say that we have to decrease our economy. This proposal will actually increase the economy with new jobs and new industries. Rightly handled, we will take the lead globally to show that a modern, industrialised economy is possible to do in accordance with the biological and physical laws that nature has given us.

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield PHILLIPS
text: – (inaudible) by electing a record number of Green MEPs. Across the world we are mobilising in our millions to protect our planet, led often by young people themselves, and as a result, the European Commission is following our lead and now talking the green talk. It is down to us to make sure that their Green Deal walks the green walk, because their Green Deal is anything but new. But it’s not too late. Commissioner Timmermans, you have the opportunity before you to tackle head on the three crises facing Europe: the crisis of inequality, the democratic crisis and the climate crisis. A genuine Green New Deal rises to these challenges. It engages with unions, bringing everyone with us on this exciting journey through citizen-led assemblies and, crucially, raises the standard of living and creates new jobs. We have just 10 years to curb the worst effects of the climate crisis. This Green Deal must not be yet another greenwash. It must deliver a positive reality for all European citizens.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: – Madam President, the EU’s climate policies have failed. They have resulted in energy prices substantially higher than America, where energy costs are 80% lower than Europe. It’s no wonder America is having an industrial renaissance at Europe’s expense. The Renewable Energy Directive has led to perverse incentives and environmental damage caused by expensive wind farms that kill migratory birds and bats and harm our precious marine resources. They have created a crony capitalist subsidy-seeking climate industrial complex that has now a vast lobbying base here in Brussels. Biomass is the most egregious renewable that illustrates the idiocy and hypocrisy. Drax, for example, generates electricity by burning wood chips imported from virgin forests in Louisiana and shipped to the UK. For this they receive a subsidy of 850 million from the British taxpayer. It’s a blatant transfer of wealth from the poor to the rich. The Commission’s new green deal will result in massive de-industrialisation. The destruction of nature, let alone the destruction of economies of Europe, is on your hands.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We Swedish Conservatives welcome The Green Deal. It is important for Europe to raise its ambitions with regard to the climate, but the most important thing, of course, is what we are also doing. If we are serious about phasing out dirty and fossil energy from Europe, then we will need much more of renewable energy. We will also need more carbon-free nuclear power. This will be an important part of many of our Member States. I think it is important for the Commission to understand that this is also a central objective for us to achieve our very high climate targets. If Europe is to set an example in the world, it is also important that we can reconcile our climate policy also with growth and prosperity. Because that is how we can build a policy that will have the support of the citizens of Europe, and that is how we can set an example in the world.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President. Welcome, Vice President. I will not waste much time thanking the work of these last weeks and congratulating the Commission on this communication. I will fundamentally stop at an issue that has caught my attention. It is true that the financial plan for this whole new agenda is still uncertain. I believe that the Commission has quantified the needs well, but we have very important challenges ahead of us. I would like to refer to the diffuse situation in which the communication leaves the possibility of establishing a border adjustment on imported goods and the importation of CO2. Right now we're already suffering from a carbon leak. Across Europe, companies are going outside our continent to produce cheaper, but also to produce polluting much more, putting at risk the efforts that the European Union is making and what we are going to make in the coming years. And yet in their submission they say that they perceive a risk that can materialize and that, if it materializes, they would raise this measure. This measure is necessary and they have to push it forward now.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, you are addressing two points with your proposals that are particularly close to my heart. Firstly, I am pleased that you are announcing a new and much-needed forestry strategy. However, i am sorry that this is only reduced to afforestation and reforestation. These terms are still undefined, and we will have to discuss them intensively here. In addition, the new forestry strategy must focus on the multifunctional role of forests. Secondly, farm to fork. I expected a comprehensive strategy for sustainable food. So far, however, I see only additional obligations for farmers. As things stand, the strategy does not go beyond "farm". There are no proposals on the practicality of these requirements for farmers. In addition, there are no further steps in the supply chain. Sustainability of food is not only a question of production, but also of processing, trade, imported goods and consumer information. You have to add to that, Commissioner, the road to the fork.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: – Madam President, President von der Leyen, Vice-President Timmermans, today you are taking an important step in presenting the European Green Deal. We’re pleased to say this. We’re pleased to see it. We’ve been waiting some time for it to happen. Some people say climate action costs too much. They say it threatens our freedom. They say, ‘go slow’. You must rise above this and show your resolve, because you cannot put a price on a planet that is healthy and safe for our children. In Ireland, the Society of Saint Vincent de Paul tell us 140 000 people – children – live in homes with leaks, damp and rot. We want a new deal for Europe that provides warm homes, tackles fuel poverty and makes jobs and breaks the cycle of poverty. In Europe, poor air quality kills half a million people every year. We want to phase out fossil fuels, promote renewables and improve people’s health and save the planet. Your Transport Commissioner’s first recorded meeting, however, was with the heads of ten airlines. Why should they have priority boarding when train and bus companies are burdened with unfair taxes? We want – (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you have called us as a matter of urgency to present this Green New Deal, but the President leaves almost immediately. If we see good morning from morning, if that is the respect that the Commission intends to have for the only democratically elected institution, allow me, but we are really very concerned. Let us hope, therefore, that they are not just promises! Dear Vice-President Timmermans, your Commission cannot afford to disappoint those who want to live and work in a healthy environment, those who want to eat healthily, those who want to secure bridges, roads and schools threatened by climate change. Is your plan enough to reassure us? Allow me to be sceptical, especially since the real revolution must begin to take place within us. There will be no revolution if we do not stop chasing growth at any cost, or without a complete rethink of macroeconomic rules. The unbunding of green investments and a plan for an energy transition from polluting sources such as coal, yes, but also from gas, but also for industrial transitions from steel production, is essential. The Just Transition Fund doesn't have to be a rain fund to clear your conscience. The planetary emergency needs an emergency response but also a vision response and not financial alchemy... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwa All european Union countries have signed the Paris Agreement, so it is clear that they support the EU's Green Agenda and its main objective: climate neutrality by 2050. Moreover, it is not only about the climate, but also about clean air, biodiversity, clean oceans. And our green deal should show the whole world that this can be done by developing the economy, preserving growth, creating jobs.  For this to happen, we must first of all exercise moderation in formulating the first phase of this programme (this until 2030), also prepare a detailed impact assessment that will answer many of the questions that we have today and also maintain technological neutrality and perhaps, most importantly, take into account the fundamental differences between the regions of the Union at the start point of the programme. That is why we need a separate programme in the Union's multiannual budget – a fair transition fund, especially for the mining regions on our map.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Timmermans, I congratulate you on what you have presented today, a very complete package that gives us great hope for the future of the citizens of Europe and the European Union.
