You said one very important thing in this document: all citizens and all Member States and all regions must be supported because no one should be left behind. I would like to ask you to look at the Just Transition Fund mechanism because, as presented last week in the European Parliament - I am talking about Romania - the cost of achieving the 2030 targets is almost 4% of gross domestic product and an amount of almost EUR 80 billion to be spent in each of the following years up to 2030 , so almost eight billion euros annually. That's a lot of money. However, we must deal with the coal regions (two hundred and something thousand families) − this cost is very high − and at the same time ensure that we also have energy security. I am counting on you and your desire to help us and the involvement of the European Commission so that we can achieve our 2030 targets.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Madam President, the Commission's first appearance to present the Green Pact is a sign of what its priorities and political determination are, and my political group thanks you. They present us with necessary and ambitious measures. The first climate law, strengthening our ambition to achieve climate neutrality in 2050, border protection of the competitiveness of a European industry that innovates and does not pollute and protect biodiversity by farmers and ranchers in a new Community policy. It is indeed a great challenge and a great opportunity. And this Green Pact is a new growth strategy for Europe that must put us at the forefront of knowledge, innovation and technology – which will be green – but which must also create jobs and new opportunities for our companies. All this in a transition that must be socially just, must be responsible, equitable and inclusive. You will have the support of our Group.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Madam President, Mr Timmermans, there is no doubt that the fight against global warming cannot wait, but it cannot end up disappointing either. From this perspective, it is necessary to attach all the importance of a European industrial strategy that is capable of developing technologies that have a decisive impact on reducing emissions while gaining global competitiveness. This requires that the emphasis placed on technological innovation be equal to and as determined as that placed on emission reduction targets and translates into very specific decisions such as making a big effort to incentivize and finance technological innovation. And there's the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation. There is no doubt that in Madrid governments can reach many agreements, but here we must make a decision on the budget for the next Framework Programme for Research and Innovation. The Green Pact is a truly ambitious project. We all share the needs to deal decisively with climate change, but we must move forward and not disappoint.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Frans Timmermans, the European Green Deal must have a huge ambition: to become the pact for the strategy of fair and inclusive sustainable growth for Europe in the next decade. But this ambition can only be credible if it mobilises the right financial resources. Financial institutions such as the EIB and the ECB are crucial. We are at the key moment in negotiating the next multiannual financial framework. The proposal that is on the table, and which will be debated tomorrow at the European Council, is unacceptable, and moreover, it is completely out of line with the political discourse of the leaders. If we are indeed committed to the fight against climate change, the Union budget must grow. The transition is everyone's and everyone's. All Member States, without exception, should support this transition and all should be supported.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am absolutely convinced that we must take action on climate change. The weather conditions become more extreme and harvests fail. But we cannot leave that to one sector or country. We need to tackle this in a European way and make sure that the rest of the world goes along with it. Together with people and companies we have to do this, but we can only do that if we take their concerns and challenges with us, otherwise this will not work. Support is crucial. There's no point in people not being able to pay their bills or if we're pushing our economy into recession. I therefore call for a move from green idealism to realism and common sense. Because we don't live in a paper reality. We need to take measures based on science and effectiveness, such as the emissions trading system. We have to focus on innovation, because that also creates jobs. We must make use of European economies of scale. And whether we like it or not, we don't have the luxury of excluding techniques like nuclear energy or CO2 storage based on gut feelings.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, climate change is the most pressing challenge we are facing. It has a wide impact across the world. It change fast our society. I am confident that there will be a response to these challenges and I’m totally decided, as President of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), in contributing to achieve the ambitious targets on climate policies with a coherent industrial policy, with a just, inclusive transition and maintaining the security of energy supply in the Union. Building on the success of the Energy Union, we need to strengthen our efforts to improve energy efficiency, speed up deployment of clean energy and technologies, increase interconnectivity between regions and further integrate our energy single market. In securing our lead in tackling climate change, we need also to work towards climate innovation and digitisation, increasing the number of jobs and also remaining competitive and assuring growth.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, scientists have long done their job and demonstrated urgency. Young people have put the issue at the top of the political agenda. And here's the European New Green Deal. As far as we are concerned, this is not just an environmental programme or a programme to combat climate change. This is the European project, not only of the coming years but of the coming decades. This project, for the essence of the large investment programme, also has the potential to help all European citizens to improve. Consider, for example, the right to clean air in all our cities and municipalities. Consider, for example, the hundreds of thousands of jobs that are created and where they are lost, we take people to prepare them for another job. Remember, for example, that our energy bill will fall because we are investing in new buildings. We also need to extend this to the rest of the world. Therefore, trade will become one of the essential components in the New Green Deal.

name: Martin HLAVÁČEK
text: – Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, your concept is in many respects based on fiscal and financial instruments and will therefore undoubtedly have an impact on the lives and wallets of all our citizens and companies. I believe that you care about citizens across the EU supporting your objectives in the long term. This can only happen if you tell them the truth not only about the objectives, but also about the impact of the proposed changes. You would therefore like to ask that all the proposals and future decisions contained should be accompanied by a transparent and truthful study of the economic and social impacts. Not all regions in the EU have the same starting point. We have coal, steel, automotive and other industrial regions that, without a viable strategy and sufficient funding, will not be the winners of this process. Please don't forget that. This is nothing less than the social and economic cohesion of Europe. Ambition on paper looks good, more importantly, how we will fulfil it. Therefore, openness to all technologies, including non-transmission, such as nuclear energy, is important.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, thanks for your patience with my strictness on time, and I have another bad announcement to make. We have to be finished by 4:10, and I therefore have been urged to cancel the catch-the-eye procedure. I regret that it is not my call. I am just required to do that.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I appreciate the development of the European Green Agreement, which is the first continental plan to protect the future of the Earth. Here in the European Parliament, we are also working to find a solution to the challenges of climate change as soon as possible, which is why we have also supported the declaration of a climate emergency. In order to achieve climate neutrality in 2050, a financial framework should be developed that takes the interests of citizens into account and does not pass on the additional costs incurred to consumers. Energy and food prices should not be allowed to rise, so I believe that we need a solution based on cost-effectiveness that adheres to the principle of technological neutrality and pays particular attention to supporting the poorest regions of the EU. Therefore, the European Green Agreement must not only be ambitious, but one that takes into account the needs of the Member States and protects consumers and the competitiveness of the Union.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Timmermans, dear Frans, we are facing a global emergency that is manifested in the increasingly frequent climatic disasters afflicting our citizens and our farmers. We need a common and highly coordinated approach to this challenge, and the ambitious pact presented today between the Union and its citizens is certainly an encouraging assumption of this responsibility. However, without the firm participation of our farmers, any prospect of climate change mitigation becomes unfeasible. European farmers must be guided and adequately encouraged to make a further qualitative leap forward in the provision of environmental services that can benefit the whole community. Instead, Mr Frans, the proposal to reform the CAP on which we are working delegates to the Member States the planning of a strategy to counter this momentous challenge, in fact a renationalisation of European intervention for rural areas. That is why, Mr Frans, we need a more common and stronger agricultural policy, so that this can really be the key to climate change... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, comhghairdeachas leis an Uachtarán, Ursula, as ucht teacht chugainn inniu tar éis deich lá in oifig leis na spriocanna agus na moltaí a chuir sí romhainn inniu. Aontaím go huile agus go hiomlán le chuile rud a dúirt sí agus beidh mé ag comhoibriú léi chun na spriocanna sin a bhaint amach. I was very pleased about was that President Ursula von der Leyen promised that no one will be left behind. Her announcement of a just transition mechanism, far greater in scale than expected, is very welcome and will be welcomed especially in carbon-intensive areas, such as the peatlands in the Irish Midlands, coal areas in Poland, etc. When you have everybody on board, then you can be successful. As we say in Irish: ‘ní neart go cur le chéile’ (there is no strength without unity). Finally, I just want to make one point. My country was a laggard up until now, but with myself and yourself, Mr Vice-President, and our colleagues, we will ensure that it will be a leader in this area from now on.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, the transition to a sustainable society can only be achieved if we take everyone with us. Unfortunately, it has become clear today that some governments do not want to go along with it. They are currently blocking a law for cleaner investments. It's bizarre, because we need to mobilize the money. It is important that we achieve a social and sustainable climate. We do not want an even bigger gap between rich and poor, which is why I am pleased that climate poverty is explicitly taken into account. We need to invest in new jobs for people who are still working in polluting industries, and we need to create jobs for people who are still looking for work. That is why the Labour Party wants today's communication to lead to a deal, so that we are indeed the first continent to be climate neutral in 2050. French, as far as we're concerned, you're the right man at the right time in the right place to lead the fight.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, the Green Deal programme presented today paves the way for us towards carbon neutrality in 2050. I think it is very good that it takes very broad account of the various sectors of society and how we need to reform industry, the circular economy, food production, biodiversity, sustainable transport, chemicals legislation and trade policy. It is quite clear that such a significant change towards a carbon-neutral society means that our industry must be significantly reformed. Similarly, it is also reforming societies and means that we must be able to stimulate innovation in Europe, so that our industry can also benefit from this. We will be more competitive in the future. However, many things need to be looked at very carefully, including the reform of the emissions trading system and carbon emissions, because it makes no sense to create overlapping systems. We must constantly strive for a model that reduces emissions as much as possible on market terms and efficiently.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Madam President, Mr Frans Timmermans, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has done. Yes, climate change is one of the biggest challenges facing Europe, and the European Green Deal can be the right answer. European cohesion policy, which is one of the EU's largest and most important investment instruments, is already focusing on climate action. It should do so even more in the future. That is what we are currently working on in the negotiations on the future cohesion policy. However, we also need greater support from the Member States, which are still holding back at the moment. We need to make sure that the Green Deal is properly funded. This also means that we cannot do anything with less money; on the contrary, we need new ones, we need fresh money so that European funds can help in the fight against climate change and in the fight for a fair transition. We need all the partners, not only the Commission, not only the European Parliament, but also the Member States.

name: Álvaro AMARO
text: – Madam President, this renewed ambition which has been presented today needs realism, as the President said, and funding. The ecological pact must increasingly be a development pact. We all know that new goals require new means and more technological, financial or even methodological resources. The plan of the field at the table is important, but we will only have something on the table with agriculture and farmers and these are men and women who occupy the territory, fight rural abandonment and, as the President said, more traditional products for the table will mean a great challenge for the occupation of these territorial areas so often abandoned in our Europe. European farmers have this double burden of ensuring food security and, on the other hand, helping to combat climate change. They are the big part of the solution.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I’ve listened very carefully to this debate and I’m really excited by the fact that this Parliament has expressed such broad support for the European Green Deal. This is a great start of what is going to be quite a bumpy road, where we will need both institutions to concentrate on all the elements that we need to make the Green Deal work. First of all, let me say here today that I want to congratulate Greta Thunberg for having been nominated Person of the Year by Time magazine. I think this is a great sign that this generation – our kids – are leading the way, and as a parent, there’s nothing more beautiful than when you see that your kids are leading the way. But that’s not the only reason why I believe we need to act now. The reason I believe we need to act now is because the facts are staring us in the face, and I think if you are a responsible Member of Parliament, if you’re in the responsible position in the Commission, if you’re a citizen, if you’re a parent, you do not have the luxury to ignore the facts. Look at what’s happening in Greenland. Look at what’s happening globally with our climate. Look at the desertification. Look at the erratic weather. Look at the people suffering because of this erratic weather across Europe. Look at what’s happening to our biodiversity as we speak. We do not have the luxury to ignore this any more. And look at another thing that’s happening. We are in the middle of the fourth industrial revolution. That is going to change our economy, our industry, whether we like it or not, whether we act or not. So the question we have to face today as Europeans is this: are we going to try and be masters of this momentous change, of this paradigm shift, or are we just going to let it happen, and then others will be the masters of it and we can just be the subjects of what others will decide? This is the fundamental question we have to answer, and the Green Deal is not a blueprint. It’s a roadmap. It’s an extended open hand to you and to all the stakeholders, whether it’s businesses, whether it’s NGOs, whether it’s trade unions, whether it’s citizens, whether it’s cities, whether it’s regions, to be part of a discussion of how we are going to reorganise our society in a just way so that it reflects the values we want to stand for. And we need to do this because Mother Earth is fed up with this behaviour. And you know, she was able to exist for millennia without human beings; she will be able to exist for other millennia without human beings. We’d better make sure we create an existence in balance with her so that we can continue to exist as human beings for millennia. And this is the responsibility we have before our kids. But let me make a point, because it was said often: this is costly. Yes, but don’t forget what the cost is of not acting. We see it every day. It was also said we have to be sure we take the right decisions. Yes, that is why every proposal the Commission is going to put on the table will be assessed for impact. Impact assessment will be an essential element of our analysis, but we will do this in a very, very speedy and comprehensive way. For instance. to determine exactly what the reduction by 2030 should be, from 50 to -55% – we want to have an impact assessment on that. But we want to be ready with that impact assessment early in the summer next year, so that the European Union is extremely well prepared, with a climate law for COP26 in Glasgow, so that we can lead the way. I bring back a message from Madrid – the COP, where I’m going to go back and present the Green Deal tomorrow. The message is this: we need European leadership. The message is also this: some of us are insecure about what we should do. But if Europe leads, we might go in the same direction. I had meetings with ministers from many countries saying: climate neutrality by 2050 is a good idea, we might do things the same way. With the Chinese we are in a debate. Are we going to have collective global leadership on this? Yes or no? We need to work on that, because if we do it together, the impact will be much bigger. But at the end of the day it is very important that this Parliament take this in hand and make sure that Parliament has a leading role, together with the Commission, to convince our Member States and Council to do the right thing. And if we begin by enshrining in law that by 2050 Europe will be climate neutral, then we can take steps back until today and just chart the map that we need to get there, and then we will discuss the measures we will need to take, whether it’s on ETS, whether it’s on emissions, whether it’s on taxation, whether it’s on all sorts of other measures to make our industry circular, to make sure that there are jobs in this new economy. But finally, I want to add one thing which is very, very important. You know, the biggest risk here I see is that those who are most vulnerable in climate change see themselves also as most vulnerable in the answer to climate change, so that they start resisting the Green Deal because they feel that they are vulnerable. And at the end of the day, if they resist the Green Deal and they stop it, they will be the first victims of the consequences of not doing the right thing. So that’s why – and this is a fundamental point – if this is not a social Green Deal, the Green Deal will not happen. If this is not a Green Deal where the most vulnerable regions in Europe – coalmining regions and others – do not see solidarity from other parts of Europe, it will not happen. So we need a level of solidarity with vulnerable individuals and vulnerable regions to make sure the Green Deal can be delivered for all our citizens. And let me end, because Mr Lange quoted ‘Man on the Moon’, so I obviously though of the famous moon speech by JFK, and let me just amend it slightly and end with that. We choose to go (to the moon in his case), we choose to go for climate neutrality in 2050 and do the other things, not because they are easy but because they are hard, because that goal will serve to organise and measure the best of our energies and skills, because that challenge is one that we are willing to accept, one we are unwilling to postpone and one which we intend to win. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the January part-session I. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Writing. I welcome the fact that Mrs von der Leyen has just said in her speech that the Green Deal needs an appropriately equipped multiannual financial framework to meet the challenges. Without a strong EU financial framework, the Leyens Green Deal is worth nothing. In addition to a strong climate law, we need more european public investment to make our infrastructure climate neutral. The framework for this is, above all, the multiannual financial framework. While von der Leyen presents her plans for the Green Deal in the European Parliament, a few hundred metres further, the German Federal Government and other states are blocking higher investments in the EU and risk missing the climate targets. With the old figures, we will not be able to shape the future. We expect von der Leyen to adapt the financial framework to the Green Deal and to present Germany with its own proposals for more climate investment. The Federal Government must actively work on a compromise proposal. What is needed is a budget of 1.3% of gross national income and a reform of own resources, as proposed by the European Parliament across the political groups. Genuine ecological own resources, such as a CO2 tax or a plastic tax, would be a start here. A European digital tax, which taxes Amazon, Facebook, and Google, would also be important to finance investments and create justice.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – Energy saving helps to keep our planet livable, but it is also economically beneficial to the saver. Estonian buildings still waste more energy than the exact same buildings in Finland. There are plenty of energy savings opportunities in transport. The Drive-sharing Service Bolt allows you to use one resource – the car – dozens of times more efficiently. Innovation must be supported. In Estonia there are excellent supercapacitor developments, development of parcel robots, development of fuel cells or hydrogen energy. Instead of considering an investment in a pre-refinery, the Estonian government should support innovation.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – Farmers are the first to feel the impact of climate change. Yet bear in mind the pressure on their shoulders by the rigorous standards of the future CAP, the budget cuts, the unfair competition triggered by the Mercosur trade agreement and the international trade disputes countermeasures. It is, thus, fundamental to design policies that accompany our farmers towards this transition, instead of putting even more pressure on them. Forestry also plays a crucial role in addressing climate change. It has significant potential to reduce emissions, sequester carbon and boost economies in a sustainable manner. With over 40% of the EU’s land area covered by forests, it is clear that the European Green Deal must include an updated post-2020 EU Forest Strategy, to put the legislation in line with renewed climate and biodiversity ambitions. However, as the Commission knows, each Member States has its specificities. During the last plenary debate on the protection of forests, Romanian illegal logging was discussed. I call on the Commission to explain all the concrete initiatives which might be taken in order to protect Romanian forests and its biodiversity.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Bans on plastic straws will no longer help us – we need a complete transformation of our economic system. We are facing "the need to go beyond the framework of gradually improving efficiency and increasing the level of implementation of environmental policy". This is just part of a report published last Wednesday by the European Environment Agency (EEA) on assessing Europe's environmental performance. After all the calls from the scientific community, I welcome the promise to prepare the 'New Green Deal' project in my first 100 days in office. His proposals must, however, go far beyond the 'greening' of economic growth that we already know. The need to reduce emissions is indisputable. Like the move away from coal to RENEWABLES. The "New Green Deal" must propose a new fund for a just transition – one in which thousands of miners in Poland will not suffer and post-mining regions will be able to maintain their cultural identity fairly. We now need radical steps so that in 10 years' time we can look our children in the eye. These must be very balanced steps so that everyone can benefit from the transformation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The Commission presented today a new growth model for the European Union. The extremely ambitious Green Course initiative should help to create a fairer, safer, more sustainable, more socially responsible and prosperous society that meets the expectations of our people. However, the challenges ahead of the European Union in the area of climate change, the transition to neutral energy, clean transport and many other named initiatives can only be successfully implemented if we turn them into opportunities. In this forward-looking process, we must not forget the problems of today's people, and we must be able to respond appropriately to them. And for this, we need to mobilise political will in all institutions, especially in terms of fair and sufficient funding, especially for social policies in the next financial perspective. It will be very difficult to persuade our citizens to contribute to the implementation of a new economic model if they do not feel socially safe. I therefore very much hope that the Green Course initiative will maintain a strong social dimension and that the social impact assessment will be ensured in all policy areas.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. "We cannot repeat enough, and President Trump was right to do so, although his decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement is not without criticism, that the West, and in particular Europe, will not be able to bear the burden and responsibility for climate change alone and, therefore, the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. However, this is the perspective that emerges through international commitments in this area, which all too often leave india or China with pride of place. Moreover, environmental intransigence encloses the European Union in its own contradictions. Contradictions first between its ambitious objectives and the reality of a contrasting territory, where some states like Poland still rely heavily on coal. Contradiction then between these same aspirations and a development model based on the primacy of free trade against states and large international groups against small producers. The resolution of these fundamental dilemmas depends on the environmental future of Europe as well as that of the world.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – As the eu's only directly elected body, the European Parliament, as the only directly elected body of the EU, will have to take a firm stance in its legislative, supervisory and budgetary powers, as it directly responds to more than 500 million European voters and citizens, and in particular to the future generation of electoral beneficiaries who have made their climate action demands clear on the streets of European cities over the last year. The European Green Agreement, especially in the light of achieving climate targets by 2050, is not a choice, but a necessity. Only one of the most optimal measures to implement the policies that are a constitutional part of this agreement will be selected. This process of seeking compromise must in no way be to the detriment of the most vulnerable, both to the community and to individuals, in countries to which objective factors prevent them from being equal in this "race" for a carbon-free future. Not only politics and the economy, but also every EU citizen, has a challenging challenge ahead of them. The role of an informed individual, above all, as a consumer and, at the same time, let us not forget, the bearer of all human rights, is a fragment in the mosaic of the Green Agreement, but it can have an essential and, above all, sustainable effect in the successful implementation of it. It is known which rights can be re-restricted or suspended in the state of emergency that we have declared in the European Parliament.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: in writing. – I welcome the presentation of the European Green Deal. We have a historic opportunity ahead and I hope the European Union will be up to the challenge. The European Green Deal will aim to make Europe the first climate—neutral continent by 2050. It is indeed very ambitious, but we cannot ignore this strong need for change. I believe that the green transition will require a common effort. EU institutions, Member States, local authorities, civil society, citizens, businesses: everybody is called to play their part. If we want the European Green Deal to deliver its ambitious results, we need to fight for adequate resources to finance it. Research and innovation will be paramount in order to make sure that citizens and enterprises keep up with technological process and will be able to meet the targets the Green Deal is going to set. The expectations of the upcoming Just Transition Fund are incredibly high. If we want it to succeed, we need to make sure that not only the coal regions of our Union, but also its energy—intensive areas, including islands, can benefit from it. The transition to a clean planet for all must leave no one behind.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – Decounting the much green propaganda, this pact is little left. Of what's left, a lot isn't good. They want to widen the carbon market, the business that some do by buying and selling permits to pollute. They want to insist on neoliberal policies which, in addition to social injustices and economic inequality, create many of the ecological imbalances we face. It's not because they say a thousand times the word "green" that changes the nature of the policies that brought us here. There is a need to reduce dependence on fossil fuels. Certainly. But if we want to do this with social justice and environmental sustainability, public control of the energy sector is required, which cannot be in the hands of the multinationals that control it. A society based on rampant consumerism - paint it as you wish - is not sustainable. Where are measures to combat programmed obsolescence? Where are measures promoting quality and free public transport as an alternative to the car? Also behind this green screen is the old and always current confrontation between capital and labor.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The European Green Agreement set a goal of achieving climate neutrality by 2050 while maintaining economic competitiveness and social justice. It is a big task that can only be approached responsibly and with the complexity of the challenge in mind. The Motto of the European Union is 'United in Diversity'. The European Green Agreement cannot be based on any other principle. Therefore, the diversity of the Member States, their different natural conditions and their different starting positions on the road to climate neutrality should be duly respected. One of the pillars of this is the principle of technology neutrality. In a climate crisis, we do not have the luxury of favouring certain technologies and stigmatising others. For a successful transition, we need all the low-carbon solutions without exception. Finally, unity in diversity must mean justice. I trust that, in addition to the fine words, this will be embodied in a fund and mechanism to support a fair transition of the necessary size. If the principle of justice is violated, we will soon face a social and economic emergency, which is unacceptable to me.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Thank you very much to the Commission for presenting the proposal for a New Green Deal for Europe. It is undoubtedly high time that we treated the issue of climate change not only as an urgent matter, but as a state of supreme necessity. This is our most important action in this term of the European Parliament, which is what the young people involved in the climate strikes want from us. It is to them and future generations that we must ensure that the world can live. And we have to do it wisely.  Energy transition is a necessity, and it is necessary to carry it out as soon as possible. It is also necessary to carry it out in a socially and culturally safe manner. Mining regions such as Silesia in particular face a huge challenge and all transformation mechanisms at EU and national level must enable them to meet this challenge. We need wise decisions, money, cover-up measures and, above all, an explanation of the need for change for our citizens, so that they feel the authors of the success of the transformation.  It is from Europe that the best legislation and technologies should come together to achieve Europe's climate neutrality by 2050. The opportunities resulting from the ecological transformation will bring the greatest benefit to those who act at the earliest and fastest. As an MEP from Silesia, a mining region in the process of transformation, I will work very actively on the implementation of the New Green Deal for Europe.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Today we are talking about the European Green Course, a path that must be walked by our citizens, regions, industry and energy. The ambition of carbon neutrality in 2050 and the 2030 targets should make us have a pragmatic approach and a clear assessment of the challenges and decisions we need to take. We must maintain and develop our global competitiveness and increase our energy security by not excluding working solutions. Innovation, human potential and scientific achievements are the tools to ensure that every citizen, region and economic sector in Europe successfully makes its green journey. Climate change and environmental protection, a global technological race and limited access to resources are a clear answer as to why we need the Green Course, but we need to have a concrete preliminary assessment of each goal and how this preserves our role as a global model for peaceful human development. Let's not forget that there are still 50 million people in the world. europeans are energy poor and a number of sectors, including energy, face challenges in their digital transition. Every change has its own price and the citizens of Europe know it. Development, Security and Leadership is what they expect to receive in exchange for their work and effort!

name: Leszek MILLER
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I believe that the implementation of the European Green Deal is rightly a fundamental political priority for the new Commission, because it is impossible to pass indifferently alongside the negative effects of the degradation of our environment. The success of this project lies in the belief of societies, especially central and eastern European countries, including Polish, that it is a project for the benefit of the people and not against people. Green Deal antagonists will certainly equate it with extreme ideology or a jump in money. It is already easy to predict that this will be the main narrative of opponents of change in Europe. I am convinced that the European Commission should precede the implementation of the Green Deal with a very wide-ranging educational and information action to understand to the citizens of the Union what the essence of this project is. That it is not intended to make European citizens slaves to new green corporations, but merely to serve the good of all of us and future generations.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Green Deal is a new strategy aimed at improving health, quality of life and the environment by transforming the European economic model. It also envisages an action plan for the circular economy, including the reduction of plastic waste. Combating climate change, however, is a global challenge and therefore requires international and, above all, coordinated external action.  The achievement of the climate objectives, including climate neutrality, presented by Ursula von der Leyen will have a real impact on stopping progressive environmental degradation only if we are all involved in the transition process. Everyone is responsible for the future of our planet: we – members and the youngest – students.  The EU should become a leader in environmental action by promoting its objectives as a model for global agreements on, in particular, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and biodiversity. A draft of the world's first climate law is due to be presented in March next year, which will permanently set a climate neutrality target by 2050. We should all the more strengthen our efforts to increase the coherence of development and climate policies. These include conducting sustainable trade with other parts of the world, as well as building partnerships with developing countries to help them transform themselves towards greener economies.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – I welcome The European Green Deal (EGD) launched today, this roadmap to action, as no one left behind! EGD stresses the importance of making infrastructure climate-resilient and it recognises the challenges and opportunities that lay ahead for sectors, cities, communities and regions in this transition and of creating decent work and quality jobs. The implementation of the UN 2030 Agenda (17 SDGs) and the Paris Agreement means to adapt and build resilience to climate change should ensure stability, recovery and a better balance between inclusive societies and prosperous economies. The climate emergency imposes more action in order to achieve the Paris Agreement goals with a significant share of the investments for combating climate change should be realised by the private sector, further to the public funding. A just and fair transition policy framework and an investment plan with a visible positive impact on employment will create the conditions to better align EU climate targets for 2030 and 2050. Having people at heard of transition is the responsible way forward to a net-zero greenhouse gas economy. It is about people and their daily lives, about the way Europeans work, transport themselves and live together.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The new Green Deal will be an uneven challenge for many countries, but above all for societies, especially given the different starting points. Although the whole initiative was born of lofty assumptions, if it is ideologized, it can have severe and profound side effects that many of you are afraid to talk about today.  The law--a-law process must be based on sound analysis and opinion of all parties involved in the transformation. Both colleagues in the Commission and in Parliament will have to take into account the views of those with whom they disagree on a daily basis and arm themselves with exceptional sensitivity. We will end differently, as in the recent negotiations on sustainable finances, the so-called taxonomy of the New Green Deal, where the Presidents of the Renew negotiations, the rapporteurs and part of the negotiating team, including the Commission representative, tinged for more than 4.5 hours in a 'private' trilogy and secretly agreed on the terms of the agreement, while distorting the transparency of the process. Do we want a new Green Deal behind closed doors, imposed by force on citizens who were in the minority?  On various issues, we may disagree, but it is your duty to listen to all Europeans and make sure that they do not feel excluded from key decisions. Otherwise, there is nothing to dream about the success of this initiative.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: in writing. – We are faced with two major global challenges: climate change and digitalisation. The EU is set to be the first continent to achieve climate neutrality by 2050 and this requires a transformation, an environmental transformation and a digital transformation. At the same time, we are at the forefront of an industrial revolution, Industry 4.0. To achieve the transition in a just and social way, a Just Transition Mechanism can help regions transform towards a less carbon dependent economy that leaves no one behind. The Green Deal puts forward a growth strategy for the EU with the aim of reaching our climate commitments, while creating business opportunities for the European industry and our SMEs, as well as quality jobs. Digital technologies, such as AI and 5G, are uniquely positioned to provide effective tools for the shift towards a circular and lean economy and decrease the carbon footprint across many industries, but at the same time the digital sector needs to become sustainable. And in the transition towards a sustainable economy, we need a smart future-looking strategy that places innovation at its heart and ensures leadership for the EU, while safeguarding our industrial, digital and strategic sovereignty.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: in writing. – The European Green Deal presented by Commission to the MEPs in an extraordinary plenary session in Brussels today lacks necessary measures to tackle some key factors behind the climate crisis. One area that has not been addressed properly is industrial farming – a practice that is growing and intensifying in Europe. Factory farms produce staggering quantities of waste, pollute our land, air and water, and massively contribute to climate change. It is widely known that factory farming is an unsustainable method of raising animals – and one that is not compatible with the safe and wholesome food supply that the European Green Deal promised. Limiting the over-consumption of meat and dairy products is also essential to ward off climate crisis. Therefore, the absence of policies to stop industrial farming or to promote a shift towards plant-based diets is alarming. When designing a fair, healthy and environmentally friendly food system, the EU must tackle the over-consumption of meat and dairy products and factory farms. We need a change in dietary patterns and farming practices. Without such change, the headline objective behind the new environmental law cannot be achieved. We need concrete plan and actions to stop this destructive, wasteful, inefficient and cruel system.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The Communication from the European Commission launching the European Ecological Pact strengthens the coherence and adherence to the ground of a progressive, inclusive and sustainable agenda to address the climate emergency and to give the European Union a leading role in the energy transition and the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.  The fair transition mechanism to be presented at the beginning of 2020 should allow no region, territory or sector to be left behind in achieving the objectives. I also highlight the importance of the commitment to present, during the first half of 2020, a new industrial strategy and a "climate law", which will make the emission reduction target more ambitious. The option of applying a carbon tax under WTO rules is a sign that the financial leverage of the pact will not question the financing of cohesion and convergence policies.  The European Union cannot hesitate in a practice that is also inspiring to the rest of the world. We need to mobilise policy makers as well as civil society. In this context, the European Commission's decision to present the Ecological Pact first to the European Parliament has a relevant political significance.
